thread.title: JSE closes lower as global market rallies fade | Markets
thread.title_full: JSE closes lower as global market rallies fade | Markets | BDlive

author: Madeleine van Niekerk
title: JSE closes lower as global market rallies fade | Markets
text:
Picture: MICHAEL ETTERSHANK Related articles Rand recoups some losses but remains fragile Bonds take cue from firmer rand and US Treasuries Unwanted diesel, jet fuel cargoes could sink oil prices Gold rises on dipping dollar, uncertainty over Fed THE JSE closed lower on Monday as global market rallies faded after gains on Friday after China cut interest rates and the prospects of more monetary stimulus by the European Central Bank buoyed global markets.
Meanwhile, a US new home sales report on Monday disappointed, with 468,000 contracts signed in September, far lower than market expectations of 550,000, weighing negatively on market sentiment.
Global markets responded positively to the People’s Bank of China (PBoC) decision to lower interest rates on Friday afternoon.
The PBoC cut both benchmark interest rates by 25 basis points and the reserve-requirement ratio by 50 basis points last Friday, the third such combined cuts in 2015.
Markets are now looking ahead to the US Federal Reserve’s October meeting that concludes on Wednesday, with expectations for a rate rise this year having diminished due to global growth concerns.
The meeting of the Bank of Japan on Friday is also in focus, as the central bank may announce further monetary stimulus.
At the JSE’s close, the Dow Jones industrial average was flat (-0.04%) at 17,640 points in early trading.
At 5pm, the JSE all share was down 0.27% at 54,150.70 points and the blue-chip top 40 index gave back 0.47%. The JSE was last at these levels in May.
The gold index led the upside on the bourse, closing 1.61% firmer amid a higher gold price. Platinums and resources retreated 2.14% and 0.78%, respectively.
Among individual shares on the JSE, Anglo American closed 1.36% lower at R124 and oil company Sasol collected 122% to R436.53, despite a softer Brent crude oil price.
AngloGold Ashanti gained 2% to R123.49 and Impala Platinum shed 4.65% to R41 amid a softer platinum price.
Telecommunications company MTN fell 12.49% to R167 after MTN said the Nigerian Communications Commission had imposed a fine of $5.2bn on MTN Nigeria.
The fine relates to the timing of the disconnection of 5.1-million MTN Nigerian subscribers in August and September 2015, MTN said.
Media company and industrial heavyweight Naspers closed 1.2% higher after announcing on Monday it is selling its online Czech businesses for $201m.
Construction companies Group Five and Wilson Bayly Holmes-Ovcon closed 1.37% higher at R21.49 and 2.83% firmer at R132.55, respectively.
The Competition Commission on Monday said it had referred the two companies to the Competition Tribunal for collusion relating to the N17 link road between New Canada and Soccer City (N17 project).
